span.a: You are currently on this page - COVID-19 Resources

td.h2: Educating and Protecting Our Students and Community

td.div: DearLittle Chute Area School Districtfamilies,

The health and safety of our students and staff are always our number one priority. We are closing our school buildings under order to help contain the spread of COVID-19, the coronavirus in Wisconsin. We know that keeping children at home may cause difficulties for your children and families as you jugglework, child care and other challenges, and our staff are committed to doing everythingwe can to help make this as positive an experience as possible for your children.

Gov. Tony Evers on March 17, 2020 ordered the closure of all K-12 Wisconsin schools, public and private, from Wednesday, March 18 for the duration of the public health emergency or until a subsequent order lifts this restriction. The announcement affects almost 855,000 students in more than 400 districts across the state - and adds Wisconsin to a growing list ofstates to close schools.

Kids and families across Wisconsin often depend on our schools to access food and care," Evers said. "We are going to continue working to do everything we can to ensure kids and families have the resources and support they need while schools are closed.

TheLittle Chute Area School Districtwill be closed as of March 17. All after-school activities and athletics, including practices, also will be canceled until further notice.
For the latest communication sent to LCASD parents please refer to "Family Communication" in the blue section at the rightside or at the bottom of your screen.

td.h3: Free Meals Available During School Closure
td.div: The Little Chute Area School District has applied for a special program through the State of Wisconsin that will allow us to serve meals during the school closure. Our food service partner, Taher, will be providing free pre-packaged, grab-and-go Lunch and Breakfast meals to ANY child age 18 and under. The grab-and-go meals will include an entree, fruit/vegetable, and milk. Each day, children will receive two (2) FREE pre-packaged meals (lunch for that day and breakfast for the following day).
This program will begin Thursday, March 19 and continue weekdays (Monday - Friday). We will not be providing meals during pre-planned absences (Spring Break).

li.div: Children must be 18 years old or under.
Children do not need to be school age nor attending the Little Chute Area School District to qualify.
Everyone is welcome to participate, there is no income limit.

ul.li: To order meals for the week of April 20 (Monday through Friday), please complete School Closure Meal Order Form no later than noon on Friday, April 17.

td.div: Meals will need to be picked up at the Intermediate/Middle/High School between 10:30 and 11:30 a.m. EACH day.

Following Governor Evers mandate from March 13, all schools are to close beginning Wednesday, March 18. Our Distance/Digital Learning Days will start on March 18.The district recognizes that the minutes outlined below are minimum expectations for students during the closure.We encourage students to continue the physical activity, music practice, drawing, and reading during this time.

li.div: 4K: 30 minutes per school day, 10 minutes per day of choice reading should be included in this
Grades K-2: Two hours per school day, 20 minutes per day of choice reading should be included in this.
Grades 3-4: Three hours per school day, 30 minutes per day of choice reading should be included in this.
Grades 5-8: Four hours of learning per school day, 30 minutes per day of choice reading should beincluded in this.
Grades 9-12: Four hours of learning per school day.

td.div: Teachers and other professional staff are available to provide resources and work digitally with students andfamilies throughout the school closure. Teachers in grades 5-12 will provide instructional resources throughGoogle Classroom (LCCPA will also use Canvas) and answer questions via email. We understand thatsituations may arise that may inhibit your child from meeting these expectations and encourage you to contact teachers.

div.br: Elementary in grades 4K-4 will receive distance learning packets that parents can pick up on Wednesday,March 18. Look for emailed information from the elementary principal.

td.div: Students in grades 5-12 are asked to login daily to Google Classroom (or Canvas for LCCPA) to view coursecontent, progress, and feedback. The following steps is your students daily checklist:

ul.li: Create a learning plan for the day
Send and receive messages to the teacher for support

td.div: For students with Special Education needs, teachers will be contacting you to discuss your childs Individual Education Plan (IEP). The Department of Education has ongoing efforts to assist students, teachers, and education leaders as part of the Administrations unprecedented, whole-of-government response to the viral outbreak.

We are dedicated to serving you and your child. This is unchartered territory for all of us. Please know we desire to offer the best services we can while providing safety for your child, your family, and our staff. Please dont hesitate to reach out to our Special Education/Pupil Services Director Heidi Schmidtat hschmidt@littlechute.k12.wi.usif you have any concerns.
LCASD Letter to Families Regarding SpecEd- 03/18/2020
Families that do not have Internet and Wi-Fi access should complete ourHome Needs Assessment Form.
LCASD Technology Help Desk is available if you have a hardware failure or need more help.
Email: lcasdtech@littlechute.k12.wi.us
Families can come to the Intermediate/Middle/High School Office weekdays between 8am and 3pm to drop-off and/or pick-up equipment.

ul.li: Parents need to call or email the help desk to report a hardware failure or device issue.
A loaner device will be available for pickup the following day.
Broken equipment needs to be dropped off when the loaner is picked up.
Once the repair work is complete the parent will be notified by the Tech Staff to come and exchange the loaner for the students repaired device.

div.div: Public Service Commission of Wisconsin (PSC) recently launched acustomer service phone line for people who need help locating phone or internet serviceduring the COVID-19 public health emergency. Callers can speak with a PSCConsumer Affairs staff person who will walk through internet and phone service optionsavailable in their area and discuss eligibility for discounts on critical communicationsservices. Families can call their Internet and Phone Helpline number - 1 (608) 267-3595 or visit their website foradditional information related to Offers for Internet Access at Home.

div.b: Due to the nature of the COVID -19 situation, please CALL AHEAD to any non-crisis agencyto guarantee they are still operating.

li.div: 211 - will answer questions on how to reach various agencies
St. Johns - 325. Pine St. Little Chute, WI 788-9033
Loaves & Fishes Food Pantry - 2011 E. Main St. 766-9131
St. Luke Lutheran Church - 705 Greenfield Dr. 788-4408
For medical issues, visit our School Nurse Resource Website from Samantha Busko.

td.h5: Visit our Community Wellness/Mindfulness Linkspage for more information.

td.div: This is a rapidly evolving situation, with the World Health Organization declaring Coronavirus a pandemic, the President and Governordeclaring it a public health emergencyand the President issuing a month-long ban effective March 13on all travel from Europe, including the UKand Ireland,to the U.S.
The state of Wisconsin Department of Health Services (DHS) is asking schools and organizations to:

ul.li: Avoid traveling to areas in the US with sustained community transmission of COVID-19 (currently Washington, New York, and California).See map of US sustained community transmission of COVID-19.
Self-quarantine for 14 days upon return for anyone who travels to any U.S. states with confirmed community spread of COVID-19.

td.p: Many families have travel plans for spring break. If your family is planning to travel to a country with a Level 3 travel health notice, the CDC is asking you to self-quarantine for 14 days before returning to school. Read more about travel on the CDC's website.

We appreciate your patience with this fluid situation and we will continue to update you as needed. Please rest assured that we will continue to put your students safety first. If you have any questions, reach out to Karen Moore, business manager at kmoore@littlechute.k12.wi.us.

ul.li: Director of Curriculum, Instruction, and Assessment
